Inherited characteristics are transferred from parents to their offspring through DNA. DNA, which stands for deoxyribonucleic acid, is the hereditary material in humans and almost all other organisms. Every cell in a person's body has the same DNA. Most DNA is located in the cell nucleus (where it is called nuclear DNA), but a small amount of DNA can also be found in the mitochondria (known as mitochondrial DNA or mtDNA).

When organisms reproduce, they pass along copies of their DNA to their offspring. In sexual reproduction, offspring receive half of their DNA from each parent. This mixture of parental DNA is what creates inherited characteristics, which can include physical traits like eye color and height, as well as susceptibility to certain diseases and even aspects of behavior. The specific mechanics behind this involve the segregation and assortment of chromosomes during the formation of reproductive cells (gametes) and their subsequent fusion during fertilization.
